title: Study in Brandenburg an der Havel | Study in Germany

text_sections.section_11: Brandenburg an der Havel OLD BUILDINGS, YOUNG LIFE
text_sections.section_12: Not far from Berlin lies the charming city of Brandenburg an der Havel. Thanks to the Havel River and its nearby lakes, the city offers a diverse range of water sports and quiet places to have fun and relax.
text_sections.section_18: Brandenburg is especially pretty in the summertime. With the Havel River flowing through the city and numerous greens, you will find lots of quiet spots in Brandenburg to relax, study and learn in the middle of nature.
text_sections.section_19: A thousand years of history await you in the centre of town. The medieval city walls and various churches are quite beautiful. You should definitely pay a visit to  (https://www.dom-brandenburg.de/en/the-cathedral/) . People often call it the “mother of all Märkisch churches“ which reflects its cultural significance for the region.
text_sections.section_20: The rents are cheaper if you live in the outskirts of Brandenburg. The only drawback is that it’s too far to walk or take your bike to the university of applied sciences or into town. But don’t worry – every student receives a “semester ticket“ which allows you to use public transportation for free.
text_sections.section_21: The Studentenwerk offers a wide selection of reasonably priced rooms to students. The apartments vary in size: You can either live alone in a one-person flat or move into a flat share (WG) with up to five flat mates.
text_sections.section_22: When you need to take a break, Brandenburg an der Havel offers a wide range of possibilities.
text_sections.section_23: The General Student Committee (  (https://stuve.th-brandenburg.de/wir/allgemeiner-studierendenausschuss/) ) at the University of Applied Sciences organises cultural events as well and has a quite varied programme. The annual student ball and the popular Campusfest are big attractions for the student community.
text_sections.section_24: If you ever get cabin fever, simply get on the train. In just 20 minutes, you can reach  (/en/germany/cities/potsdam/) , and in about 45 minutes, you’re in  (/en/germany/cities/berlin/) ! It’s worth taking a trip to both cities, and with your semester ticket, you can get there quite inexpensively.
text_sections.section_25: The university sports programme offers a wide range of sports courses. In addition to classical sports like football and handball, you can also try archery for example.
